title: Shankar Hangud:Indian American Techie Drives To Police Station With A Dead Body, Tells Cops He Killed Three More People
text:
Indian American Techie Drives To Police Station With A Dead Body, Tells Cops He Killed Three More People

Indian American Techie Drives To Police Station With A Dead Body, Tells Cops He Killed Three More People

Police officers in Roseville, Northern California were left shocked after a man casually walked into the police station and told them that there was a dead body in his car.

Shankar Hangud walked into the Mount Shasta police station on Monday and told investigators he had killed the man in his car.

What left the cops even more shocked was his further admission that he had killed three other people at his apartment in Roseville, about 260 miles south of Mount Shasta.

Based on his admission, the Roseville police traced the address and found three dead bodies, an adult and two juveniles as he had said.

Hangud, a 53-year-old Indian-origin IT professional was then transported back to Placer County, Calif., where he is being held without bail on four counts of murder.

Police believe that Hangud committed the murders over a few days and later drove to Mount Shasta with the fourth body.

AP

But what has left the investigators puzzled is the motive of the murder, which still remains a mystery.

On his LinkedIn profile, Hangud describes himself as a data specialist working with a firm called Social Interest Solutions.

Police said they were not ready to disclose a motive for Hangud's alleged acts; however, tax records showed that Hangud faced a federal tax lien of USD 178,603 from the Internal Revenue Service this year. Police believe Hangud "drove from Roseville and travelled to unknown places in Northern California, and ended up in Mount Shasta," Simon said.

Court records show that Hangud's only previous encounter with law enforcement was for speeding in Placer County in 2016 in 2001.

"This incident has touched the lives of many in the area," Simon said at a news conference on Tuesday, adding such a killing had not occurred in the Placer County city of 130,000 in his recent memory. "It's a very sad, sad situation."

"The suspect himself drove to the Mt. Shasta Police Department with one of the victims in his car and made a confession to them to start off this investigation," Simon said.

Mt. Shasta Police chief Parish Cross said he and another officer went outside to the car to verify what the man had said was true. "These are things that just don't happen everyday and when they do, it is upsetting," said Cross.

"I've been in the business for a long time and I've seen a lot of unusual occurrences, just upsetting occurrences, but this one here is a whole new level. We are still in shock," said an official at KDRV.com, an affiliate of the ABC Television Network, reported.
